UAV-Enabled Asynchronous Federated Learning

Zhiyuan Zhai, Xiaojun Yuan, , Xin Wang, , and Huiyuan Yang
Abstract

To exploit unprecedented data generation in mobile edge networks, federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising alternative to the conventional centralized machine learning (ML). By collectively training a unified learning model on edge devices, FL bypasses the need of direct data transmission, thereby addressing problems such as latency issues and privacy concerns inherent in centralized ML. However, FL still faces some critical challenges in deployment. One major challenge called straggler issue severely limits FL’s coverage where the device with the weakest channel condition becomes the bottleneck of the model aggregation performance. Besides, the huge uplink communication overhead compromises the effectiveness of FL, which is particularly pronounced in large-scale systems. To address the straggler issue, we propose the integration of an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) as the parameter server (UAV-PS) to coordinate the FL implementation. We further employ over-the-air computation technique that leverages the superposition property of wireless channels for efficient uplink communication. Specifically, in this paper, we develop a novel UAV-enabled over-the-air asynchronous FL (UAV-AFL) framework which supports the UAV-PS in updating the model continuously to enhance the learning performance. Moreover, we introduce a ‘staleness upper bound’ metric to control the asynchronous level in AFL and conduct a convergence analysis to quantitatively capture the impact of model asynchrony, device selection and communication errors on the UAV-AFL learning performance. Based on this, a unified communication-learning problem is formulated to maximize asymptotical learning performance by optimizing the UAV-PS trajectory, device selection and over-the-air transceiver design. Simulation results reveal valuable insights into the UAV-AFL system and demonstrate that the proposed UAV-AFL scheme achieves substantially learning efficiency improvement compared with the state-of-the-art approaches.

Index Terms:
Asynchronous federated learning, UAV communication, over-the-air computation, staleness, device selection, trajectory optimization.

I Introduction

Extensive data available on mobile edge devices have sparked considerable interest in the development of artificial intelligence (AI) services, such as image recognition and natural language processing [1], [2]. However, traditional machine learning (ML) requires the collection of data in a centralized server for model training, which incurs substantial energy and bandwidth costs, significant time delays, and potential privacy concerns [3]. Federated learning (FL), as a novel ML paradigm, has emerged to tackle these problems [4]. In a typical FL framework, each edge device computes local model updates based on its individual dataset and subsequently transmits the model update to a parameter server (PS) for model aggregation. The global model is then updated at the PS and shared with the participating devices. In this way, FL replaces direct data transmission with the model updates (gradients) transmission, which not only alleviates the communication burden but also safeguards the confidentiality of local data.

Despite the above advantages, the huge uplink communication overhead incurred in the iterative learning process remains a significant bottleneck of FL [4]. Over-the-air computation [5, 6] for FL uplink model aggregation is a promising technique to reduce this communication cost. By using the superposition property of electromagnetic waves in wireless channels, edge devices can concurrently transmit their gradients utilizing the same time-frequency resources. The authors in [5] thus introduce over-the-air model aggregation for FL, and the result demonstrates substantial communication efficiency improvement and latency reduction when compared to orthogonal multiple access (OMA) schemes. This approach is extended to multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) scenarios in [6] where over-the-air computation is applied.

In addition to the communication burden, FL also encounters a new design challenge, namely the straggler issue [7, 8]. Since the PS needs to aggregate gradients from all participating devices, the devices with poor channel conditions (i.e., stragglers) always introduce huge communication errors into the aggregated results. This is particularly true when FL is deployed over a wide range of distributed devices where the errors from distant stragglers severely impair the overall aggregation performance. In this context, using an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) as PS (UAV-PS) is a promising approach to provide FL services. This is because the UAV has the ability to move closer to the stragglers and ensure reliable communication links with them. The enhanced capabilities, such as superior communication quality and expanded coverage can be attained by utilizing the high mobility and on-demand deployment ability of UAV [9], [10]. For this reason, the authors in [11] propose to deploy a UAV as a network relay, where the UAV collects model updates from devices and then forward them to the model owner for improving the FL coverage. Moreover, in order to minimize a fairness metric regarding device computing time, a UAV-PS trajectory optimization is carried out in [12].

Till now, the UAV-assisted FL system using over-the-air computation technique has only been investigated in [13] and [14]. In particular, [13] introduces a hierarchical aggregation approach where UAV-PS collects gradients from devices at various locations and merges them at the end of each iteration. [14] dispatches the UAV-PS to assist with the aggregation of different learning models and determines the transmission scheduling using greedy deflation approach. However, these studies [11, 12, 13, 14], while successfully integrating UAVs into the FL system to enhance learning performance, have not addressed a pivotal issue: The synchronous structure of FL is inherently incompatible with the asynchronous nature of UAV-assisted communication systems. Specifically, in the FL system, the model aggregation is only finished when all the gradients of devices are collected. However, the UAV-PS can only collect the gradients of the nearby devices (i.e., a subset of all devices). This procedural incompatibility leads to a significant delay in model update until the UAV-PS navigates through the entire service area and collects gradients from all devices, which severely impairs the overall efficiency of the learning process. A feasible solution to mitigate this incompatibility is to allow the UAV-PS to execute one FL iteration exclusively with the nearby devices. In this approach, the UAV-PS broadcasts the global model to these adjacent devices, and the latter then use the model for gradient computation. Subsequently, the UAV-PS collects the computed gradients and updates the model parameters. After that, the UAV-PS moves to another area and begins new FL iteration with the nearby devices. However, while this scheme reduces the latency of model updates, it requires the UAV-PS to hover over the serviced devices when they conduct local gradient computation. This time-consuming local computation process111In the internet of things (IoT) networks, edge devices often require several seconds for completing a single gradient descent (GD) algorithm due to their limited CPU capacity[15],[16], which is significantly greater than the gradient transmission time. could also adversely impact the overall learning efficiency.

To fully unleash the system potential and maximize the learning efficiency, we develop a novel UAV-enabled over-the-air asynchronous FL (AFL) scheme. This scheme is generally obtained by further changing the order of the model aggregation and broadcast steps in the framework of aforementioned solution. Since the aggregation happens before the broadcast step, some aggregated gradients are computed based on different versions of the global model, which leads to an AFL problem. Specifically, in the proposed UAV-enabled over-the-air AFL (UAV-AFL) scheme, the UAV-PS selects some devices to communicate with, collects these devices’ gradients over-the-air, updates the model and then performs model broadcasting to these selected devices. After that, these selected devices conduct local computation based on the newly received model while the UAV-PS continues the next round of AFL by selecting new devices without waiting for the local computations of these previously selected devices. Compared with conventional UAV-assisted FL settings [11, 12, 13, 14], the UAV-AFL scheme improves learning efficiency by offering a compatible asynchronous communication-learning design which allows the UAV-PS to traverse the service area to collect gradients and update models continuously.

In this paper, we investigate the potential of the UAV-AFL system by developing a unified analysis framework that captures the impact of model asynchrony, device selection and communication errors on the AFL training loss. Based on this, a joint communication-learning optimization algorithm is formulated to maximize the asymptotic learning performance. Our main contributions are summarized as follows.

  • •

    We study a UAV-assisted FL system where a UAV-PS is deployed to perform over-the-air aggregation over line-of-sight (LoS) channels. We propose a novel UAV-AFL scheme to improve the learning efficiency. This scheme has two advantages: 1) The UAV-PS can immediately updates the global model upon the reception of the aggregated gradients. 2) The UAV-PS can collect the newly computed gradients for model update when devices are conducting local computation.

  • •

    We introduce a metric called ‘staleness upper bound’, i.e., the maximal version discrepancy among the models maintained by all edge devices, to characterize the level of asynchrony in the UAV-AFL system. Then, a rigorous convergence analysis on the learning loss is carried out by taking the model asynchrony, device selection and communication errors into account. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first attempt to analyze the convergence of asynchronous learning/optimization in the presence of general communication error and device selection loss.

  • •

    We formulate a communication-learning co-design optimization problem to enhance the learning performance of the UAV-AFL based on the convergence analysis. An effective algorithm is developed to solve the problem. Specifically, we transform the original problem via geometric programming (GP), and design a two-layer penalty-based algorithm using successive convex approximation (SCA) principle to jointly optimize the UAV trajectory, device selection and transceiver design.

Simulation results under different system settings provide an in-depth study of the trade-offs between over-the-air aggregation quality, model update rates and asynchronous level, which offers valuable insights for the UAV-AFL system design. The comparison results indicate that the proposed UAV-AFL scheme achieves a substantial improvement in learning efficiency compared to the existing state-of-the-art solutions.

II-B UAV-Assisted Communication System

A UAV-assisted communication network is used to fulfill the FL task, where a UAV-operated parameter server (i.e., UAV-PS) is deployed to coordinate the edge devices performing collaborative training. We employ a three-dimensional Cartesian coordinates system, where the coordinates of the m𝑚m-th ground device are 𝐰m=[xm,ym,0],∀msubscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝑥𝑚subscript𝑦𝑚0for-all𝑚\mathbf{w}_{m}=\left[x_{m},y_{m},0\right],\forall m. We assume that the UAV-PS maintains a constant flight altitude H𝐻H and the position of the UAV-PS remains constant during one time slot with duration δtsubscript𝛿𝑡\delta_{t}. The coordinates of the UAV-PS at time slot k𝑘k, denoted by 𝐪​(k)𝐪𝑘\mathbf{q}(k), can be expressed as 𝐪​(k)=[x​(k),y​(k),H]𝐪𝑘𝑥𝑘𝑦𝑘𝐻\mathbf{q}(k)=\left[x(k),y(k),H\right]. We then have the following mechanical constraints

𝐚k=𝐯​(k+1)−𝐯​(k)δt,∥𝐚k∥≤amax,∀k,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐚𝑘𝐯𝑘1𝐯𝑘subscript𝛿𝑡delimited-∥∥subscript𝐚𝑘subscript𝑎for-all𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{a}_{k}=\frac{\mathbf{v}(k+1)-\mathbf{v}(k)}{\delta_{t}},\left\lVert\mathbf{a}_{k}\right\rVert\leq a_{\max},\forall k, (5)
𝐪​(0)=𝐪​(K)=𝐪F,𝐪0𝐪𝐾subscript𝐪𝐹\displaystyle\mathbf{q}(0)=\mathbf{q}(K)=\mathbf{q}_{F}, (6)

where vmaxsubscript𝑣v_{\max} (or amaxsubscript𝑎a_{\max}) denotes the maximal speed (or acceleration) of the UAV-PS, K𝐾K is the total number of time slots, and 𝐪Fsubscript𝐪𝐹\mathbf{q}_{F} denotes the initial and final dispatch position of the UAV-PS.

We assume that the channel state information (CSI) is available at edge devices and the UAV-PS [17], and the Doppler effect arising from the movement of the UAV-PS can be effectively compensated at the receiver. Moreover, due to the ground-to-air nature of UAV communication, we focus on the line-of-sight (LoS) channels for the connection links. Therefore, the channels connecting the devices to the UAV-PS adhere to the free-space path loss model, expressed as

III UAV-Enabled Over-the-Air AFL Framework

III-A Motivation

In the conventional UAV-assisted FL literature [11, 12, 13, 14], the system conducts the following steps iteratively: 1) The UAV-PS broadcasts the global model to all devices. 2) All devices conduct local gradient computation based on the received model. 3) The UAV-PS navigates through the entire service area and collects gradients from all devices. 4) The UAV-PS finally aggregates the gradients and use it to update the global model. Here, the UAV-PS can only update the global model after all devices have completed local computations and the UAV-PS has finalized the gradient collection of all devices (i.e., after step 3 and 4). Hence, this approach needs excessively long time to carry out a single model update, which significantly impairs learning efficiency and effectiveness.

To address this issue, a straightforward choice is to allow each FL iteration to involve only the devices located near the UAV-PS. In this method, the UAV-PS traverses the entire service area and provides FL service sequentially to the nearby devices. When the UAV-PS approaches some devices, the system conducts the following steps: 1) The UAV-PS broadcasts the global model to the near devices. 2) These devices compute the gradients locally. 3) The UAV-PS collects the newly computed gradients from these devices. 4) The UAV-PS aggregates the gradients and updates the global model. In this way, the UAV-PS can directly utilize the gradients from near devices to update the global model, thereby enhancing the learning efficiency. However, to collect the gradients (step 4), the UAV-PS in this approach cannot do anything but hover near the devices to wait for them completing local computations, which also compromises the system efficiency.

Therefore, to improve the overall learning efficiency, it is crucial to develop a strategy where the UAV-PS can operate without interruption. This strategy should enable the UAV-PS to collect gradients and update models continuously for ensuring a seamless and efficient learning process.

III-B Proposed UAV-Enabled AFL System

We consider a UAV-enabled AFL system as depicted in Fig. 1. In this system, at each time slot, the UAV-PS selects a subset of devices to communicate with. Specifically, the UAV-PS collects the gradients of the selected devices, updates the global model, and then broadcast the updated model to these devices. Subsequently, the selected devices initiate computation based on the received model, while the UAV-PS continues to collect gradients from other devices for updating the model at the same time. Denote by 𝒥k⊂ℳsubscript𝒥𝑘ℳ\mathcal{J}_{k}\subset\mathcal{M} the set of aggregation-ready devices in the k𝑘k-th time slot, i.e., the devices that complete their local computation and are ready for aggregation at time slot k𝑘k. In the k𝑘k-th time slot, the system conducts the following procedures:

  • •

    Device selection: The UAV-PS selects a subset of devices in 𝒥k∩𝒩ksubscript𝒥𝑘subscript𝒩𝑘\mathcal{J}_{k}\cap\mathcal{N}_{k} to participate in the aggregation process. Let ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘\mathcal{M}_{k} be the set of selected devices in the k𝑘k-th time slot. We define am​(k)subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘a_{m}(k) as an indicator function of the selection status of the m𝑚m-th device in the k𝑘k-th time slot. That is, am​(k)subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘a_{m}(k) = 1 if m∈ℳk𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}, and am​(k)subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘a_{m}(k) = 0 otherwise.

  • •

    Gradient aggregation: The devices in ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘\mathcal{M}_{k} transmit the computed gradients 𝐠m​(k),m∈ℳksubscript𝐠𝑚𝑘𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘\mathbf{g}_{m}(k),m\in\mathcal{M}_{k} to the UAV-PS via the wireless channels. Here, 𝐠m​(k)subscript𝐠𝑚𝑘\mathbf{g}_{m}(k) is represented as

    𝐠m​(k)=∇fm​(𝐱​(k−τm,k)),m∈ℳk,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐠𝑚𝑘∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝐱𝑘subscript𝜏𝑚𝑘𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{g}_{m}(k)=\nabla f_{m}(\mathbf{x}(k-\tau_{m,k})),m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}, (8)

    where 𝐱​(k−τm,k)𝐱𝑘subscript𝜏𝑚𝑘\mathbf{x}(k-\tau_{m,k}) denotes the global model of time slot k−τm,k𝑘subscript𝜏𝑚𝑘k-\tau_{m,k}, ∇fm​(𝐱​(k−τm,k))∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝐱𝑘subscript𝜏𝑚𝑘\nabla f_{m}(\mathbf{x}(k-\tau_{m,k})) is the gradient of device m𝑚m with respect to the model 𝐱=𝐱​(k−τm,k)𝐱𝐱𝑘subscript𝜏𝑚𝑘\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}({k-\tau_{m,k})}, and τm,k=k−maxk′<k⁡{k′∣m∈ℳk′}subscript𝜏𝑚𝑘𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑘′𝑘conditionalsuperscript𝑘′𝑚subscriptℳsuperscript𝑘′~{}\tau_{m,k}=k-\max_{k^{\prime}<k}\left\{k^{\prime}\mid m\in\mathcal{M}_{k^{\prime}}\right\} is referred to as staleness [18] of device m𝑚m in time slot k𝑘k. Guided by the received signals, the UAV-PS obtains an estimate 𝐠^​(k)^𝐠𝑘\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k) of the desired aggregated gradient 𝐠​(k)𝐠𝑘\mathbf{g}(k). The desired gradient 𝐠​(k)𝐠𝑘\mathbf{g}(k) is given by

    𝐠​(k)=1|ℳk|​∑m∈ℳk𝐠m​(k).𝐠𝑘1subscriptℳ𝑘subscript𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘subscript𝐠𝑚𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{g}(k)=\frac{1}{\left|\mathcal{M}_{k}\right|}\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}}\mathbf{g}_{m}(k). (9)

    However, due to the impact of channel fading and communication noise, we in general have 𝐠^​(k)≠𝐠​(k)^𝐠𝑘𝐠𝑘\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k)\neq\mathbf{g}(k). With 𝐠^​(k)^𝐠𝑘\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k), the global model 𝐱​(k)𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}(k) is then updated by

    𝐱​(k+1)=𝐱​(k)−λ​𝐠^​(k),𝐱𝑘1𝐱𝑘𝜆^𝐠𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{x}(k+1)=\mathbf{x}(k)-\lambda\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k), (10)

    where λ𝜆\lambda is the learning rate.

  • •

    Model broadcast: The UAV-PS broadcasts the updated global model 𝐱​(k+1)𝐱𝑘1\mathbf{x}(k+1) to the devices m∈ℳk𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}.

  • •

    Local computation: The devices m∈ℳk𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘m\in\mathcal{M}_{k} compute their individual gradients using 𝐱​(k+1)𝐱𝑘1\mathbf{x}(k+1). Let cmsubscript𝑐𝑚c_{m} represent the computation time of the m𝑚m-th device. Hence, the devices m∈ℳk𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘m\in\mathcal{M}_{k} cannot communicate with the UAV-PS from time slot k+1𝑘1k+1 to k+cm𝑘subscript𝑐𝑚k+c_{m} inclusive.

Remark 1.

In the synchronous FL setting [19, 20, 21], all the gradients 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g}’s are guaranteed to be computed using the unified global model 𝐱​(k)𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}(k). However, in the UAV-enabled AFL system, some aggregated gradients 𝐠m​(k)subscript𝐠𝑚𝑘\mathbf{g}_{m}(k) might be computed based on the stale global model, i.e., the model 𝐱​(k′)𝐱superscript𝑘′\mathbf{x}(k^{\prime}), where k′<ksuperscript𝑘′𝑘k^{\prime}<k.

Remark 2.

Compared to the approaches in[11, 12, 13, 14], the UAV-AFL scheme provides a more efficient learning strategy. Here, the UAV-PS can seamlessly collect the newly computed gradients from edge devices and update the model parameters immediately. This feature not only accelerates the UAV-PS update rate but also increases the device computing efficiency.

III-C Over-the-Air Model Aggregation

We employ the over-the-air computation technique [5] to achieve efficient aggregation in the UAV-AFL system. Specifically, in the k𝑘k-th time slot, the selected devices m∈ℳk𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘m\in\mathcal{M}_{k} collaboratively transmit their gradients {𝐠m​(k):m∈ℳk}conditional-setsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑘𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘\{\mathbf{g}_{m}(k):m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}\} using the same time-frequency resources. By manipulating the transmit and receive equalization coefficients, the estimated weighted sum 𝐠^​(k)^𝐠𝑘\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k) in (10) can be coherently superposed at the UAV-PS. The specifics are elaborated as follows.

To perform over-the-air aggregation, the initial step is the normalization of 𝐠m​(k),m∈ℳksubscript𝐠𝑚𝑘𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘\mathbf{g}_{m}(k),m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}, which can be expressed as

𝐠~m​(k)=(𝐠m​(k)−g¯m​(k)​𝟏D×1)/vm​(k),subscript~𝐠𝑚𝑘subscript𝐠𝑚𝑘subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑘subscript1𝐷1subscript𝑣𝑚𝑘\displaystyle\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}(k)=\left(\mathbf{g}_{m}(k)-\bar{g}_{m}(k)\mathbf{1}_{D\times 1}\right)/\sqrt{v_{m}(k)}, (11)

where 𝐠~m​(k)∈ℝDsubscript~𝐠𝑚𝑘superscriptℝ𝐷\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}(k)\in\mathbb{R}^{D} is the normalized zero-mean and unit-variance version of 𝐠m​(k)subscript𝐠𝑚𝑘\mathbf{g}_{m}(k), and g¯m​(k)=1D​∑d=1Dgm(k)​(d)subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑘1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑚𝑘𝑑\bar{g}_{m}(k)=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{d=1}^{D}{g}_{m}^{(k)}(d) as well as vm​(k)=1D​∑d=1D(gm(k)​(d)−g¯m​(k))2subscript𝑣𝑚𝑘1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑚𝑘𝑑subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑘2v_{m}(k)=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{d=1}^{D}\left({g}_{m}^{(k)}(d)-\bar{g}_{m}(k)\right)^{2} are the mean and variance of 𝐠m​(k)subscript𝐠𝑚𝑘\mathbf{g}_{m}(k), respectively. By following the common practice as in [7] and [22], we assume {g¯m​(k),vm​(k)|m∈ℳk}conditional-setsubscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑘subscript𝑣𝑚𝑘𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘\left\{\bar{g}_{m}(k),v_{m}(k)|m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}\right\} to be transmitted to the UAV-PS via error-free links. We then modulate (analog modulate) 𝐠~m​(k)subscript~𝐠𝑚𝑘\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}(k) as a complex version 𝐫m​(k)∈ℂCsubscript𝐫𝑚𝑘superscriptℂ𝐶\mathbf{r}_{m}(k)\in\mathbb{C}^{C} for transmission, i.e.,

𝐫m(k)=𝐠~m(k)(1:D2)+j𝐠~m(k)(D+22:D)\displaystyle\mathbf{r}_{m}(k)=\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}(k)\Big{(}1:\frac{D}{2}\Big{)}+j\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}(k)\Big{(}\frac{D+2}{2}:D\Big{)} (12)

where we assume D𝐷D is even and C=D2𝐶𝐷2C=\frac{D}{2}. Let βm​(k)subscript𝛽𝑚𝑘\beta_{m}(k) denote the pre-processing factor of device m𝑚m at time slot k𝑘k. Then the transmit signal 𝐬m​(k)subscript𝐬𝑚𝑘\mathbf{s}_{m}(k) can be expressed as

𝐬m​(k)=βm​(k)​𝐫m​(k)∈ℂC,subscript𝐬𝑚𝑘subscript𝛽𝑚𝑘subscript𝐫𝑚𝑘superscriptℂ𝐶\displaystyle\mathbf{s}_{m}(k)=\beta_{m}(k)\mathbf{r}_{m}(k)\in\mathbb{C}^{C}, (13)

and the corresponding power constraint is 𝔼∥sm(k)[l]∥2=2|βm(k)|2≤P0\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}{\left\lVert s_{m}^{(k)}[l]\right\rVert^{2}}=2|\beta_{m}(k)|^{2}\leq P_{0}, where sm(k)​[l]superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘delimited-[]𝑙s_{m}^{(k)}[l] is the transmit signal of device m𝑚m at the l𝑙l-th channel use. To compensate the phase shift of channel hm​(k)subscriptℎ𝑚𝑘h_{m}(k), we construct βm​(k)subscript𝛽𝑚𝑘\beta_{m}(k) as βm​(k)=bm​(k)​e−j​θm​(k)subscript𝛽𝑚𝑘subscript𝑏𝑚𝑘superscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝜃𝑚𝑘\beta_{m}(k)={b_{m}(k)}e^{-j\theta_{m}(k)}, where θm​(k)subscript𝜃𝑚𝑘\theta_{m}(k) is the phase of hm​(k)subscriptℎ𝑚𝑘h_{m}(k) and bm​(k)∈ℝsubscript𝑏𝑚𝑘ℝb_{m}(k)\in\mathbb{R} is amplitude of βm​(k)subscript𝛽𝑚𝑘\beta_{m}(k). By such design, the received signal at the UAV-PS, denoted by 𝐲​(k)𝐲𝑘\mathbf{y}(k), is given by

𝐲​(k)=∑m∈ℳk|hm​(k)|​bm​(k)​𝐫m​(k)+𝐧​(k),𝐲𝑘subscript𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘subscriptℎ𝑚𝑘subscript𝑏𝑚𝑘subscript𝐫𝑚𝑘𝐧𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{y}(k)=\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}}|h_{m}(k)|{b_{m}(k)}\mathbf{r}_{m}(k)+\mathbf{n}(k), (14)

where 𝐧​(k)∈ℂC𝐧𝑘superscriptℂ𝐶\mathbf{n}(k)\in\mathbb{C}^{C} is an additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) vector with the elements following the distribution 𝒞​𝒩​(0,δn2)𝒞𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑛2\mathcal{C}\mathcal{N}\left(0,\delta_{n}^{2}\right). Subsequently, the UAV-PS employs a denoising factor ζ​(k)∈ℝ𝜁𝑘ℝ\zeta(k)\in\mathbb{R} to process the received signal 𝐲​(k)𝐲𝑘\mathbf{y}(k) as

𝐫^​(k)=ζ​(k)​𝐲​(k)=ζ​(k)​(∑m∈ℳk|hm​(k)|​bm​(k)​𝐫m​(k)+𝐧​(k)),^𝐫𝑘𝜁𝑘𝐲𝑘𝜁𝑘subscript𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘subscriptℎ𝑚𝑘subscript𝑏𝑚𝑘subscript𝐫𝑚𝑘𝐧𝑘\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{r}}(k)\!=\!\zeta(k)\mathbf{y}(k)=\!\zeta(k)\!\bigg{(}\!\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}}\!\!|h_{m}(k)|{b_{m}(k)}\mathbf{r}_{m}(k)\!+\!\mathbf{n}(k)\!\bigg{)}\!, (15)

and then the estimate 𝐠^​(k)^𝐠𝑘\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k) is finally reconstructed as

𝐠^​(k)=[Re​{𝐫^​(k)}T,Im​{𝐫^​(k)}T]T+g¯​(k)​𝟏D×1^𝐠𝑘superscriptResuperscript^𝐫𝑘TImsuperscript^𝐫𝑘TT¯𝑔𝑘subscript1𝐷1\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k)=\left[\text{Re}\left\{\hat{\mathbf{r}}(k)\right\}^{\mathrm{T}},\text{Im}\left\{\hat{\mathbf{r}}(k)\right\}^{\mathrm{T}}\right]^{\mathrm{T}}+\bar{g}(k)\mathbf{1}_{D\times 1} (16)

where g¯​(k)=1|ℳk|​∑m∈ℳkg¯m​(k)¯𝑔𝑘1subscriptℳ𝑘subscript𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑘\bar{g}(k)=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{M}_{k}|}\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}}\bar{g}_{m}{(k)} is introduced to compensate the subtracted mean of gradients g¯m​(k),m∈ℳksubscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑘𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘\bar{g}_{m}(k),m\in\mathcal{M}_{k} in the normalization step (11).

III-D Overall UAV-AFL Framework

We summarize the UAV-enabled over-the-air AFL (UAV-AFL) framework discussed above in Algorithm 1. We define the device selection, UAV-PS trajectory, device transmit amplitude gain and the UAV-PS denoising factor over K𝐾K time slots as 𝐀={am​(k)∣∀m,k}∈ℝM×K𝐀conditional-setsubscript𝑎𝑚𝑘for-all𝑚𝑘superscriptℝ𝑀𝐾\mathbf{A}=\{a_{m}(k)\mid\forall m,k\}\in\mathbb{R}^{M\times K}, 𝐐={𝐪​(k)∣∀k}∈ℝ3×K𝐐conditional-set𝐪𝑘for-all𝑘superscriptℝ3𝐾\mathbf{Q}=\{\mathbf{q}(k)\mid\forall k\}\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times K}, 𝐁={bm​(k)∣∀m,k}∈ℝM×K𝐁conditional-setsubscript𝑏𝑚𝑘for-all𝑚𝑘superscriptℝ𝑀𝐾\mathbf{B}=\{b_{m}(k)\mid\forall m,k\}\in\mathbb{R}^{M\times K}, and 𝐙={ζ​(k)∣∀k}∈ℝK𝐙conditional-set𝜁𝑘for-all𝑘superscriptℝ𝐾\mathbf{Z}=\{\zeta(k)\mid\forall k\}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}, respectively.

IV Convergence Analysis

In this section, we analyze the convergence performance of the proposed UAV-AFL system. We present several assumptions in Section IV-A and derive a tractable convergence bound by quantitatively characterizing the impact of {𝐀,𝐐,𝐁,𝐙}𝐀𝐐𝐁𝐙\{\mathbf{A},\mathbf{Q},\mathbf{B},\mathbf{Z}\} on the learning performance in Section IV-B.

IV-A Assumptions

To conduct the convergence analysis, we make the following assumptions.

Assumption 1.

(Lipschitzian gradient). The function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) is differentiable and the corresponding gradients ∇F​(⋅)∇𝐹⋅\nabla F(\cdot) is Lipschitz continuous with parameter L𝐿L, i.e.,

∥∇F​(𝐱)−∇F​(𝐲)∥≤L​∥𝐱−𝐲∥,∀𝐱,𝐲.delimited-∥∥∇𝐹𝐱∇𝐹𝐲𝐿delimited-∥∥𝐱𝐲for-all𝐱𝐲\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F(\mathbf{y})\right\rVert\leq L\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert,\forall\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}. (17)
Assumption 2.

(Strongly convex). The function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) is strongly convex with parameter μ𝜇\mu, i.e.,

F​(𝐱)≥F​(𝐲)+(𝐱−𝐲)T​∇F​(𝐲)+μ2​∥𝐱−𝐲∥2,∀𝐱,𝐲.𝐹𝐱𝐹𝐲superscript𝐱𝐲𝑇∇𝐹𝐲𝜇2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐱𝐲2for-all𝐱𝐲\displaystyle F(\mathbf{x})\geq F(\mathbf{y})\!+\!(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y})^{T}\nabla F(\mathbf{y})\!+\!\frac{\mu}{2}\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert^{2},\forall\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}. (18)
Assumption 3.

(Staleness upper bound). All staleness τm,k,∀m,ksubscript𝜏𝑚𝑘for-all𝑚𝑘\tau_{m,k},\forall m,k are bounded with the value S𝑆S, i.e., τm,k≤S,∀m,ksubscript𝜏𝑚𝑘𝑆for-all𝑚𝑘\tau_{m,k}\leq S,\forall m,k.

Assumption 4.

(Bounded gradient). The gradient ∇F​(𝐱k−am,k)∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑘subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{k-a_{m,k}}) with the staleness am,k≤2​Ssubscript𝑎𝑚𝑘2𝑆a_{m,k}\leq 2S is bounded by ∇F​(𝐱k)∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑘\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{k}) with parameters α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1} and α2subscript𝛼2\alpha_{2}, i.e.,

∥∇F​(𝐱​(k−am,k))∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹𝐱𝑘subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘2\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{x}({k-a_{m,k}}))\right\rVert^{2}
≤α1+α2​∥∇F​(𝐱​(k))∥2,∀am,k≤2​S,m,k.formulae-sequenceabsentsubscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹𝐱𝑘2for-allsubscript𝑎𝑚𝑘2𝑆𝑚𝑘\displaystyle\quad\leq\alpha_{1}+\alpha_{2}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{x}(k))\right\rVert^{2},\forall a_{m,k}\leq 2S,m,k. (19)
Assumption 5.

(Device variance). The variance of local gradient and the global counterpart is bounded with parameters δ𝛿\delta, i.e.,

∥∇fm​(𝐱)−∇F​(𝐱)∥2≤δ2,∀m,k.superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝐱∇𝐹𝐱2superscript𝛿2for-all𝑚𝑘\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla f_{m}(\mathbf{x})\!-\!\nabla F(\mathbf{x})\right\rVert^{2}\leq\delta^{2},\forall m,k. (20)

Assumptions 1, 2 and 5 are widely used in the stochastic optimization literature; see e.g., [19], [23], [24]. Assumption 1 enables us to choose an appropriate learning rate for balancing convergence speed and learning stability. Assumption 2 ensures the existence of a unique global optimum 𝐱⋆superscript𝐱⋆\mathbf{x}^{\star} for the loss function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot). Assumption 5 limits the discrepancy between the gradients of the local and global loss functions.

Assumptions 3 and 4 are introduced because of the asynchronous nature of UAV-AFL. Assumption 3 is commonly employed in the analysis of asynchronous algorithms, e.g., [25], [26]. Moreover, since the model version gap (staleness) is bounded, we can always find suitable values for α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1} and α2subscript𝛼2\alpha_{2} ensuring (4) holds.

IV-B Convergence Analysis

By comparing with the ideal model update case, we rewrite (10) as

𝐱​(k+1)=𝐱​(k)−λ​𝐠^​(k)=𝐱​(k)−λ​(∇F​(𝐱​(k))−𝐞​(k))𝐱𝑘1𝐱𝑘𝜆^𝐠𝑘𝐱𝑘𝜆∇𝐹𝐱𝑘𝐞𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{x}(k+1)\!=\!\mathbf{x}(k)\!-\!\lambda\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k)\!=\!\mathbf{x}(k)\!-\!\!\lambda\!\left(\nabla F(\mathbf{x}(k))-\mathbf{e}(k)\right) (21)

where ∇F​(𝐱​(k))=1|𝒮|​∑ξi∈𝒮∇f​(𝐱​(k),ξi)∇𝐹𝐱𝑘1𝒮subscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝒮∇𝑓𝐱𝑘subscript𝜉𝑖\nabla F(\mathbf{x}(k))=\frac{1}{\left|\mathcal{S}\right|}\sum_{\xi_{i}\in\mathcal{S}}\nabla f(\mathbf{x}(k),\xi_{i}) is the gradient of F​(𝐱)𝐹𝐱F(\mathbf{x}) at 𝐱=𝐱​(k)𝐱𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}(k), and 𝐞​(k)𝐞𝑘\mathbf{e}(k) represents the overall error introduced during the gradient evaluation process. Under the UAV-AFL framework, 𝐞​(k)𝐞𝑘\mathbf{e}(k) originates from the following three aspects:

  • •

    Communication error 𝐞c​(k)subscript𝐞𝑐𝑘\mathbf{e}_{c}(k): The inherent communication noise introduces deviations into aggregated gradient 𝐠^​(k)^𝐠𝑘\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k), consequently undermining the learning accuracy.

  • •

    Device selection error 𝐞d​(k)subscript𝐞𝑑𝑘\mathbf{e}_{d}(k): Given the common case that ℳk≠ℳsubscriptℳ𝑘ℳ\mathcal{M}_{k}\neq\mathcal{M}, the aggregated gradients are computed using a subset of data set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, which can potentially result in training imbalance and overfitting [27].

  • •

    Model Asynchrony error 𝐞a​(k)subscript𝐞𝑎𝑘\mathbf{e}_{a}(k): As shown in (8), the aggregated gradients are evaluated based on different model parameters, so the model inconsistency exists within each aggregation process.

We mathematically formulate the above analysis of 𝐞​(k)𝐞𝑘\mathbf{e}(k) as

𝐞​(k)=∇F​(𝐱​(k))−1M​∑m∈ℳ∇fm​(𝐱​(k−τm,k))⏟𝐞a​(k)𝐞𝑘subscript⏟∇𝐹𝐱𝑘1𝑀subscript𝑚ℳ∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝐱𝑘subscript𝜏𝑚𝑘subscript𝐞𝑎𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{e}(k)=\underbrace{\nabla F(\mathbf{x}(k))-\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\nabla f_{m}(\mathbf{x}({k-\tau_{m,k}}))}_{\mathbf{e}_{a}(k)}
+1M​∑m∈ℳ∇fm​(𝐱​(k−τm,k))−1|ℳk|​∑m∈ℳk∇fm​(𝐱​(k−τm,k))⏟𝐞d​(k)subscript⏟1𝑀subscript𝑚ℳ∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝐱𝑘subscript𝜏𝑚𝑘1subscriptℳ𝑘subscript𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝐱𝑘subscript𝜏𝑚𝑘subscript𝐞𝑑𝑘\displaystyle\!+\!\!\underbrace{\frac{1}{M}\!\!\!\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\!\!\!\nabla f_{m}(\mathbf{x}({k-\tau_{m,k}}))\!-\!\frac{1}{|\mathcal{M}_{k}|}\!\!\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}}\!\!\!\!\nabla f_{m}(\mathbf{x}({k-\tau_{m,k}}))}_{\mathbf{e}_{d}(k)}
+1|ℳk|​∑m∈ℳk∇fm​(𝐱​(k−τm,k))−𝐠^​(k)⏟𝐞c​(k)subscript⏟1subscriptℳ𝑘subscript𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝐱𝑘subscript𝜏𝑚𝑘^𝐠𝑘subscript𝐞𝑐𝑘\displaystyle+\underbrace{\frac{1}{|\mathcal{M}_{k}|}\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}}\nabla f_{m}(\mathbf{x}({k-\tau_{m,k}}))-\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k)}_{\mathbf{e}_{c}(k)} (22)

From (22), we see that errors 𝐞c​(k)subscript𝐞𝑐𝑘\mathbf{e}_{c}(k), 𝐞d​(k)subscript𝐞𝑑𝑘\mathbf{e}_{d}(k) and 𝐞a​(k)subscript𝐞𝑎𝑘\mathbf{e}_{a}(k) collectively compromise the model update process. The overall error 𝐞​(k)=0𝐞𝑘0\mathbf{e}(k)=0 when the conditions τm,k=0subscript𝜏𝑚𝑘0\tau_{m,k}=0, ℳk=ℳsubscriptℳ𝑘ℳ\mathcal{M}_{k}=\mathcal{M}, and 𝐠​(k)=𝐠^​(k)𝐠𝑘^𝐠𝑘\mathbf{g}(k)=\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k) hold simultaneously. We are now ready to analyze the impacts of the errors {𝐞c​(k),𝐞d​(k),𝐞a​(k)},∀ksubscript𝐞𝑐𝑘subscript𝐞𝑑𝑘subscript𝐞𝑎𝑘for-all𝑘\{\mathbf{e}_{c}(k),\mathbf{e}_{d}(k),\mathbf{e}_{a}(k)\},\forall k on the learning performance.

Proposition 1.

Under Assumptions 1-5, the communication MSE is given by (23), the device selection MSE is bounded by (24), and the model asynchrony MSE is bounded by (25), i.e.,

𝔼∥𝐞c(k)∥2=\displaystyle\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\mathbf{e}_{c}(k)\right\rVert^{2}= ∑c=1C𝔼⁡[|∑m∈ℳkΔm​(k)​rm(k)​(c)−ζ​(k)​n(k)​(c)|2],superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶𝔼superscriptsubscript𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘subscriptΔ𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑚𝑘𝑐𝜁𝑘superscript𝑛𝑘𝑐2\displaystyle\!\sum_{c=1}^{C}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\bigg{[}\bigg{|}\!\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}}\!\!\!\Delta_{m}(k)r_{m}^{(k)}(c)-\zeta(k)n^{(k)}(c)\bigg{|}^{2}\bigg{]}, (23)
𝔼∥𝐞d(k)∥2≤\displaystyle\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\mathbf{e}_{d}(k)\right\rVert^{2}\leq 8​Θ​(k)​[(M−|ℳk|)/M]2,8Θ𝑘superscriptdelimited-[]𝑀subscriptℳ𝑘𝑀2\displaystyle 8\Theta(k)\big{[}{(M-|\mathcal{M}_{k}|)}/{M}\big{]}^{2}, (24)
𝔼∥𝐞a(k)∥2≤\displaystyle\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\mathbf{e}_{a}(k)\right\rVert^{2}\leq 6​S2​Θ​(k)+6​T​𝔼​∑j=k−Sk−1∥𝐞c​(j)∥2+2​δ2,6superscript𝑆2Θ𝑘6𝑇𝔼superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑘𝑆𝑘1superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐞𝑐𝑗22superscript𝛿2\displaystyle 6S^{2}\Theta(k)+6T\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\sum_{j=k-S}^{k-1}\left\lVert\mathbf{e}_{c}(j)\right\rVert^{2}+2\delta^{2}, (25)

where Δm​(k)=vm​(k)|ℳk|−ζ​(k)​|hm​(k)|​bm​(k)subscriptΔ𝑚𝑘subscript𝑣𝑚𝑘subscriptℳ𝑘𝜁𝑘subscriptℎ𝑚𝑘subscript𝑏𝑚𝑘\Delta_{m}(k)=\frac{\sqrt{v_{m}{(k)}}}{|\mathcal{M}_{k}|}-\zeta(k)|h_{m}(k)|b_{m}(k), Θ​(k)=δ2+α1+α2​𝔼⁡[∥∇F​(𝐱​(k))∥2]Θ𝑘superscript𝛿2subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹𝐱𝑘2\Theta(k)=\delta^{2}+\alpha_{1}+\alpha_{2}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left[\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{x}(k))\right\rVert^{2}\right].

Proof.

Please refer to Appendix A. ∎

From Proposition 1, we find that the communication MSE 𝔼∥𝐞c(j)∥2\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\mathbf{e}_{c}(j)\right\rVert^{2} from the previous rounds also have impact on the model asynchrony MSE 𝔼∥𝐞a(k)∥2\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\mathbf{e}_{a}(k)\right\rVert^{2}. To obtain a tractable expression of 𝔼∥𝐞c(j)∥2\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\mathbf{e}_{c}(j)\right\rVert^{2}, we determine it by leveraging the correlation of local gradients. In this paper, we assume that the local gradients {𝐠~m​(k)∣m∈ℳk}conditional-setsubscript~𝐠𝑚𝑘𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘\{\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}(k)\mid m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}\} are independent, and the local gradient elements {g~m(k)​(d)∣m∈ℳk,∀d}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑚𝑘𝑑𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘for-all𝑑\{\tilde{g}_{m}^{(k)}(d)\mid m\in\mathcal{M}_{k},\forall d\} are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.). That is,

𝔼⁡[𝐠~i​(k)​(𝐠~j​(k))T]=𝟎,i≠j∈ℳk,formulae-sequence𝔼subscript~𝐠𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑗𝑘T0𝑖𝑗subscriptℳ𝑘\displaystyle\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left[\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{i}(k)\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{j}(k)\right)^{\mathrm{T}}\right]=\mathbf{0},~{}i\neq j\in\mathcal{M}_{k}, (26)
𝔼⁡[𝐠~m​(k)​(𝐠~m​(k))T]=𝐈,m∈ℳk.formulae-sequence𝔼subscript~𝐠𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑚𝑘T𝐈𝑚subscriptℳ𝑘\displaystyle\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left[\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}(k)\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}(k)\right)^{\mathrm{T}}\right]=\mathbf{I},~{}m\in\mathcal{M}_{k}. (27)

We thus have the following corollary.

We see from Proposition 2 that the overall convergence 𝔼⁡[F​(𝐱​(K+1))−F​(𝐱⋆)]𝔼𝐹𝐱𝐾1𝐹superscript𝐱⋆\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left[F(\mathbf{x}({K+1}))-F(\mathbf{x}^{\star})\right] is bounded by a quantity depending on UAV trajectory 𝐐𝐐\mathbf{Q}, device selection 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}, and device transmit amplitude gain 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}.

V System Optimization

In this section, to improve the learning efficiency of the UAV-AFL system, we conduct a systematic design guided by the analysis in Section IV. Specifically, we establish the objective function based on Proposition 2 and jointly optimize {𝐐,𝐀,𝐁}𝐐𝐀𝐁\{\mathbf{Q},\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}\} to maximize the learning performance.

Remark 3.

Problem (31) is a mixed-integer programming problem. To address this, we use geometric programming (GP) to transform the objective function (31a) into a tractable convex form. Then, an efficient two-layer penalty based algorithm using alternative optimization (AO) and successive convex approximation (SCA) is developed to solve this problem, as discussed in what follows.

To deal with the non-convex objective function, we introduce auxiliary variables 𝐩∈ℝ2​K𝐩superscriptℝ2𝐾\mathbf{p}\in\mathbb{R}^{2K} and 𝐲∈ℝ2​K𝐲superscriptℝ2𝐾\mathbf{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{2K} to recast problem (31) as

Problem (32) is an equivalent form of (31).

Proof.

The auxiliary variable 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} satisfying (32b) and (32c) is used to recast (31) as

min𝐐,𝐀,𝐁,𝐩subscript𝐐𝐀𝐁𝐩\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{Q},\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B},\mathbf{p}} ∑k=1Kpk​∏k′=k+1KpK+k′superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscriptproductsuperscript𝑘′𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝐾superscript𝑘′\displaystyle\quad\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}\prod_{k^{\prime}=k+1}^{K}p_{K+k^{\prime}} (33a)

Note that the objective (33a) monotonically increases with respect to 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}. Hence, the optimal 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} must be obtained at the lower boundary of the feasible region of problem (33). Consequently, at the optimum of (33), constraints (32b) and (32c) are satisfied with equality. This means the equivalence of problems (33) and (31). Moreover, the equivalence between (33) and (32) can be proved similarly by considering auxiliary variable 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}. The proof is thus complete. ∎

V-C Penalty Based Binary Constraint

The conventional method [28],[29] for tackling the binary device selection constraint (31d) is to convert the binary elements of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} to continuous-valued variables in optimization and then rounding the optimized 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}. However, the obtained 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} by this way may not satisfy the staleness constraint (31b) and the computing time constraint (31c). In this paper, a penalty based method is used to handle this constraint. We initially introduce auxiliary variables to transform (31b) into a series of equality constraints. Subsequently, to ensure the satisfaction of these equality constraints, we incorporate them into the objective function in the form of penalty terms. Specifically, we introduce 𝐀¯={a¯m​(k),∀m,k}∈ℝM×K¯𝐀subscript¯𝑎𝑚𝑘for-all𝑚𝑘superscriptℝ𝑀𝐾\bar{\mathbf{A}}=\{\bar{a}_{m}(k),\forall m,k\}\in\mathbb{R}^{M\times K} and rewrite (31d) as

am​(k)​(1−a¯m​(k))=0,am​(k)=a¯m​(k),∀m,k.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑎𝑚𝑘1subscript¯𝑎𝑚𝑘0subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘subscript¯𝑎𝑚𝑘for-all𝑚𝑘\displaystyle a_{m}(k)(1-\bar{a}_{m}(k))=0,~{}a_{m}(k)=\bar{a}_{m}(k),\forall m,k. (34)

Clearly, the elements of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} must be either 00 or 111 to comply with the constraints (34). We then introduce penalty terms in the form of (34) into the objective function [30], yielding the following formulation:

min𝐐,𝐀,𝐀¯,𝐁,𝐩,𝐲subscript𝐐𝐀¯𝐀𝐁𝐩𝐲\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{Q},\mathbf{A},\bar{\mathbf{A}},\mathbf{B},\mathbf{p},\mathbf{y}} log⁡(∑k=1Ke𝐜kT​𝐲)+1η​∑m=1MP​(𝐀,𝐀¯)superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝐜𝑘T𝐲1𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀𝑃𝐀¯𝐀\displaystyle\quad\log\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}e^{\mathbf{c}_{k}^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{y}}\right)+\frac{1}{\eta}\sum_{m=1}^{M}P(\mathbf{A},\bar{\mathbf{A}}) (35a)
s.t. (​32b​),(​32c​),(​32d​),(​31b​)−(​31e​),italic-(32bitalic-)italic-(32citalic-)italic-(32ditalic-)italic-(31bitalic-)italic-(31eitalic-)\displaystyle\quad\eqref{33b},\eqref{33c},\eqref{33d},\eqref{staleness}-\eqref{con_last},\ (35b)

where P​(𝐀,𝐀¯)=[am​(k)​(1−a¯m​(k))]2+[am​(k)−a¯m​(k)]2𝑃𝐀¯𝐀superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘1subscript¯𝑎𝑚𝑘2superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘subscript¯𝑎𝑚𝑘2P(\mathbf{A},\bar{\mathbf{A}})=[a_{m}(k)(1-\bar{a}_{m}(k))]^{2}+[a_{m}(k)-\bar{a}_{m}(k)]^{2}, and η>0𝜂0\eta>0 is employed to penalize any deviation from the equality constraint (34). It can be easily verified that the binary constraint (31d) must be satisfied as 1η→∞→1𝜂\frac{1}{\eta}\to\infty.

V-D Inner and Outer Layer Iteration

In this subsection, we propose a two-layer iterative algorithm. Specifically, in the inner layer, we decompose (35) into three sub-problems, wherein the variables 𝐀¯¯𝐀\bar{\mathbf{A}}, 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} and {𝐐,𝐁}𝐐𝐁\{\mathbf{Q},\mathbf{B}\} are optimized separately. In the outer layer, we gradually decrease the coefficient η𝜂\eta. The details are shown as follows.

V-D1 Slack Variable Optimization

We first optimize slack variable 𝐀¯¯𝐀\bar{\mathbf{A}} with given {𝐀,𝐐,𝐁}𝐀𝐐𝐁\{\mathbf{A},\mathbf{Q},\mathbf{B}\}. By dropping the irrelevant terms, 𝐀¯¯𝐀\bar{\mathbf{A}} appears exclusively in the objective function as a convex form, and the optimal value of 𝐀¯¯𝐀\bar{\mathbf{A}} is

a¯m⋆​(k)=am2​(k)+am​(k)1+am2​(k)superscriptsubscript¯𝑎𝑚⋆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑚2𝑘subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑚2𝑘\displaystyle\bar{a}_{m}^{\star}(k)=\frac{a_{m}^{2}(k)+a_{m}(k)}{1+a_{m}^{2}(k)} (36)

V-E Overall Algorithm and Complexity Analysis

We summarize the proposed algorithm in Algorithm 2.

We now analyze the complexity of Algorithm 2. The computational complexity of Algorithm 2 is dominated by steps 5 and 6. We employ the convex optimization tool CVX [31], which utilizes the standard interior-point method, to address the problems posed in these steps. Consequently, the complexity involved in steps 5 and 6 is 𝒪​((M​K)3.5)𝒪superscript𝑀𝐾3.5\mathcal{O}((MK)^{3.5}). Therefore, the overall complexity of Algorithm 2 is 𝒪​(Io​u​t​e​r​Ii​n​n​e​r​(M​K)3.5)𝒪subscript𝐼𝑜𝑢𝑡𝑒𝑟subscript𝐼𝑖𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑟superscript𝑀𝐾3.5\mathcal{O}(I_{outer}I_{inner}(MK)^{3.5}), where Io​u​t​e​rsubscript𝐼𝑜𝑢𝑡𝑒𝑟I_{outer} and Ii​n​n​e​rsubscript𝐼𝑖𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑟I_{inner} denote the numbers of iterations to achieve the precision in the inner and outer layers, respectively.

VI Numerical Result

In this section, we present numerical results to evaluate the performance of the proposed UAV-AFL scheme. These results offer valuable insights for the UAV-AFL implementation and demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed scheme.

VI-A Simulation Setup

Unless otherwise specified, the system parameters are configured as follows. We consider an area of 1 km × 1 km with a total of M=20𝑀20M=20 edge devices. The maximum flight speed vmaxsubscript𝑣v_{\max} (or acceleration amaxsubscript𝑎a_{\max}) of the UAV-PS is 505050 m/s (or 151515 m/s2superscripts2\text{s}^{2}), and the fixed flying altitude H=100𝐻100H=100 m. We set the initial and final dispatch point of UAV-PS as 𝐪0=𝐪F​(0,0,100)subscript𝐪0subscript𝐪𝐹00100\mathbf{q}_{0}=\mathbf{q}_{F}(0,0,100); the reference channel gain g0=−60subscript𝑔060g_{0}=-60 dB; the noise power σn2=−80superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛280\sigma_{n}^{2}=-80 dBm; the maximum transmit power of devices P0=0.1subscript𝑃00.1P_{0}=0.1 W; the staleness bound S=50𝑆50S=50, the number of overall time slots K=10000𝐾10000K=10000; the duration of each time slot δt=1subscript𝛿𝑡1\delta_{t}=1 s; the threshold ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} (or ϵ2subscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon_{2}) is 10−2superscript10210^{-2} (or 111). Besides, we set μ=0.2𝜇0.2\mu=0.2, L=10𝐿10L=10, δ=20𝛿20\delta=20, α1=100subscript𝛼1100\alpha_{1}=100 and α2=0.1subscript𝛼20.1\alpha_{2}=0.1. To provide a clear exhibition of the UAV-PS trajectory, we chose K=250𝐾250K=250 to obtain the optimization results, and use this as a basic cycle to conduct the UAV-AFL system training periodically for 100001000010000 time slots.

For the learning configuration, we conduct image classification task using the MNIST dataset. We train a convolutional neural network with two 5×5555\times 5 convolutional layers (each followed by 2×2222\times 2 max pooling), along with a batch normalization layer, a fully connected layer consisting of 50 units, a ReLu activation layer, and finally a softmax output layer. The loss function employed is the cross-entropy loss. The local data of edge devices are i.i.d. and equally drawn from a pool of 5×1045superscript1045\times 10^{4} images while the test data set contains 104superscript10410^{4} images.

VI-B Comparisons Based on Different Staleness Bound

In this subsection, we investigate the impact of different staleness bounds S𝑆S on the performance of the UAV-AFL system. We conduct simulations in three scenarios. In scenario 1, the devices are randomly located. In scenario 222 and 333, the devices are located within different clusters. We use the metric σ​(𝐰)≜∑m=1M∥𝐰m−𝐰¯m∥≜𝜎𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑚subscript¯𝐰𝑚\sigma(\mathbf{w})\triangleq\sum_{m=1}^{M}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{m}-\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{m}\right\rVert to roughly measure the standard deviation of devices’ geographical distributions. We introduce the communication normalized mean square error (NMSE) metric, i.e., 10​log10⁡(𝔼⁡[∥𝐠^​(k)−𝐠​(k)∥2]/∥𝐠​(k)∥2)10subscript10𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝐠𝑘𝐠𝑘2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐠𝑘210\log_{10}\left(\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left[\left\lVert\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k)-\mathbf{g}(k)\right\rVert^{2}\right]/\left\lVert\mathbf{g}(k)\right\rVert^{2}\right) to quantify the communication quality of time slot k𝑘k. Table I shows the average of the communication NMSE under K𝐾K time slots. All the presented results are averaged over 505050 Monte Carlo trials.

From Fig. 2, it is evident that a larger staleness bound provides UAV-PS more time to approach devices for gradient collection. This results in more expansive flight trajectories and reduced communication NMSE, as shown in Table I. Conversely, with a more stringent staleness constraint, the UAV-PS is compelled to complete a service cycle more rapidly, resulting in narrower trajectories. In the simulations, we note the UAV-PS stops communicating with devices under suboptimal channel conditions, especially when there is no proximal device. This behavior underscores the efficacy of our proposed algorithm in balancing device selection with communication quality, where the UAV-PS only aggregates the gradients when communication quality is favorable.

In Fig. 3, the learning performance varies distinctly across different staleness upper bounds S𝑆S. For devices located in close proximity (scenario 3, with σ​(𝐰)=153.36𝜎𝐰153.36\sigma(\mathbf{w})=153.36 m), the UAV-PS can have favorable channel quality without the necessity of nearing each device. Under such circumstances, smaller S𝑆S values exhibit higher learning efficiency, attributable to shorter service cycles and faster model update rate. For scenario 2 where devices’ location are more dispersed (σ​(𝐰)=384.53𝜎𝐰384.53\sigma(\mathbf{w})=384.53 m), communication quality becomes the main challenge. Here, a larger S𝑆S (i.e., S=30,40𝑆3040S=30,40) allows the UAV-PS the enough time to approach devices and enhance the quality of transmission, leading to improved performance. Lastly, scenario 1, with σ​(𝐰)=269.75𝜎𝐰269.75\sigma(\mathbf{w})=269.75 m, represents an intermediate case between scenarios 2 and 3. In this scenario, at the early stages of training (k<4000𝑘4000k<4000), the learning accuracy is predominantly impacted by the model update rate, making schemes with a smaller S𝑆S superior. However, as training progresses (k>4000𝑘4000k>4000), the adverse effects of communication errors become pronounced (as the model stabilizes). In this phase, schemes with a larger S𝑆S exhibit better test accuracy.

VI-C Performance Under Heterogeneous Computing Ability

In this subsection, we conduct experiments under the FL system where edge devices have heterogeneous computing abilities. In the simulations, devices are grouped into five distinct clusters based on their locations, where the devices within the same cluster are set to have the same gradient computation time cmsubscript𝑐𝑚c_{m} defined in Section III-B.

In Fig. 4, we study the performance of UAV-AFL scheme under two scenarios with different device distributions. In each scenario, both heterogeneous and homogeneous configurations are considered. For the heterogeneous setting, the computation time cmsubscript𝑐𝑚c_{m} for devices within three clusters (cyan diamond icons) is 555 s while the computation time for devices in other clusters (green pentagon icons) is 303030 s. For the homogeneous setting, the computation time cmsubscript𝑐𝑚c_{m} for each device is set to 151515 s.222By this setting, the total time for all devices to complete computation are the same under both heterogeneous and homogeneous settings.

We see from Fig. 4 (a) and (b) that the UAV-PS alters its flight strategy in the two different settings significantly. In the homogeneous setting, the UAV-PS appears to traverse and poll each device cluster in sequence. Conversely, in the heterogeneous setting, the UAV-PS prioritizes devices with superior computational abilities. For example, in scenario 1, devices with superior computational capabilities (cm=5subscript𝑐𝑚5c_{m}=5 s) are selected, on average, 1.921.921.92 times more frequently than less capable devices (cm=30subscript𝑐𝑚30c_{m}=30 s). Hence, the proposed flight strategy can leverage the gradient computation time to facilitate the model updates.

In Fig. 4 (c), we note that the heterogeneity adversely impacts the UAV-AFL learning performance. This can be understood from two perspectives. Firstly, the heterogeneity prompts the UAV-PS to rely heavily on devices with superior computational capabilities for model updates, which introduces a bias in the learned model. Secondly, heterogeneous settings often result in larger staleness degree compared to homogeneous settings. We quantify this by calculating the maximum staleness (MS), defined as max⁡{τm,k∣∀m,∀k}conditionalsubscript𝜏𝑚𝑘for-all𝑚for-all𝑘\max{\{\tau_{m,k}\mid\forall m,\forall k\}}, within our simulation. This can be considered as the tightest staleness bound S𝑆S achieve by the practical UAV-AFL system. For example, in Scenario (a), the MS values for heterogeneous and homogeneous configurations are 404040 and 282828, respectively. As suggested by Proposition 2, the learning performance is compromised by the large value of MS.

VI-D Performance Comparison With Benchmarks

In this subsection, we present a comparison of the proposed scheme with several existing state-of-the-art solutions to demonstrate the superior UAV-AFL performance. The benchmarks are as follows.

  • •

    Error free channel (Error free): We use the device schedule result i.e., 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} obtained by the Algorithm 2 to update the global model without communication error, i.e., 𝐠^​(k)=𝐠​(k)^𝐠𝑘𝐠𝑘\hat{\mathbf{g}}(k)=\mathbf{g}(k).

  • •

    Circular flight trajectory (CF)[32]: The UAV-PS flies with a circular trajectory [32] centered at (500,500,H)500500𝐻(500,500,H) using the maximum velocity. The radius of trajectory R𝑅R is determined heuristically by the average distance minimization problem, i.e., minR​∑i=1M(R−xm2+ym2)2subscript𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscript𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑚22\min_{R}\sum_{i=1}^{M}(R-\sqrt{x_{m}^{2}+y_{m}^{2}})^{2}. Given the trajectory, the device selection and the transmit amplitude gain are optimized by Algorithm 2.

  • •

    Synchronous Fly-Hover-Fly (SFHF)[20]: The UAV-PS proceeds directly from its initial position to a optimized location. At this location, the UAV-PS serves as a central PS providing synchronous FL update [20] where all devices upload the gradients over-the-air. The location 𝐪𝐪\mathbf{q} is determined by

    min𝐪,𝐛M−(∑m∈ℳg0​∥𝐪−𝐰m∥−2​bm)2∑m∈ℳg0​∥𝐪−𝐰m∥−2​bm2+δn2/2.subscript𝐪𝐛𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚ℳsubscript𝑔0superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐪subscript𝐰𝑚2subscript𝑏𝑚2subscript𝑚ℳsubscript𝑔0superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐪subscript𝐰𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑚2subscriptsuperscript𝛿2𝑛2\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{q},\mathbf{b}}\quad M-\frac{(\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}{\sqrt{g_{0}\left\lVert\mathbf{q}-\mathbf{w}_{m}\right\rVert^{-2}}b_{m})^{2}}}{\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}g_{0}\left\lVert\mathbf{q}-\mathbf{w}_{m}\right\rVert^{-2}b_{m}^{2}+\delta^{2}_{n}/2}. (39)
  • •

    Hierarchical gradient aggregation (HGA) [13]: The service strategy in [13] is simulated. Under this approach, the UAV-PS is programmed to aggregate the gradients of devices located within a threshold of dthr=250subscript𝑑thr250d_{\text{thr}}=250 m from the UAV-PS over-the-air. After all the gradients are collected, the UAV-PS further combines the previous aggregated gradients and updates the global model.

  • •

    Fully asynchronous FL with error-free communication (FAFL) [33]: Following the fully asynchronous FL principle [33], only a singular edge device is permitted to upload its gradient during one time slot. In this paradigm, the UAV-PS is mandated to sequentially approach each device to ensure effective gradient transmission. Given that each transmission is under a point-to-point communication link with low path loss, it is reasonable to assume error-free communication. The technique for solving the traveling salesman problem (TSP) is employed to optimize the UAV-PS trajectory in this scheme.

In Fig. 5, we depict the trajectory and the test accuracy of various schemes in a scenario where devices are dispersedly located (σ​(𝐰)=340.82𝜎𝐰340.82\sigma(\mathbf{w})=340.82 m). It is evident that the proposed UAV-AFL scheme offers a substantial performance enhancement in comparison to the benchmarks, and is similar to the error-free case. The disparities in learning accuracy across different schemes can be attributed to the characteristics of their service strategies. Specifically, although the accuracy of SFHF sees a rapid rise at the beginning (due to the use of all devices’ gradients for updates), it becomes stabilized at a less-than-optimal level (due to the restriction by the poor communication quality). Moreover, because of the fully asynchronous nature of FAFL, this scheme suffers from a pronounced staleness degree (MS=114MS114\text{MS}=114). Hence, its accuracy oscillates around 0.10.10.1 throughout the training period. Furthermore, the learning accuracy under the HGA method experiences a slowly ascent throughout this period. This is because the hierarchical strategy necessitates the waiting for all devices’ gradient collection, which inevitably impair the learning efficiency. Lastly, the inefficient performance of CF approach highlights the importance of trajectory optimization.

In Fig. 6, we present the trajectory and the test accuracy in a scenario where the devices are densely located (σ​(𝐰)=213.31𝜎𝐰213.31\sigma(\mathbf{w})=213.31 m). The results are similar with those depicted in Fig. 5, which demonstrates the robust performance gain achieved by the proposed scheme.

VII Conclusions

In this paper, we investigated the design of the UAV-AFL system over edge networks. We proposed a novel instant-update service strategy to improve the learning efficiency. We introduced a staleness bound metric to limit the level of AFL model asynchrony and derived an overall convergence bound by capturing the impact of model asynchrony, device selection and communication errors on the UAV-AFL learning performance. This bound represents a systematic endeavor to evaluate AFL performance under the consideration of both communication and learning perspectives. Subsequently, an optimization problem is then formulated to jointly determine UAV-PS trajectory, device selection and over-the-air transceiver design. To address this, we proposed a two-layer iterative algorithm leveraging geometric programming (GP) and successive convex approximation (SCA) for efficient problem-solving. Our numerical results demonstrated the superior effectiveness of the proposed UAV-AFL scheme when benchmarked against state-of-the-art approaches.

Appendix D Proof of Proposition 4

We introduce auxiliary variable 𝐟∈ℝK𝐟superscriptℝ𝐾\mathbf{f}\in\mathbb{R}^{K} satisfying fk≥g​(𝐚k),∀ksubscript𝑓𝑘𝑔subscript𝐚𝑘for-all𝑘f_{k}\geq g(\mathbf{a}_{k}),\forall k, and 𝐝∈ℝK𝐝superscriptℝ𝐾\mathbf{d}\in\mathbb{R}^{K} satisfying dk≤(∑m=1Mam​(k)​|hm​(k)|​bm​(k))2∑m=1Mam​(k)​|hm​(k)|2​bm​(k)2+δn2/2,∀ksubscript𝑑𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘subscriptℎ𝑚𝑘subscript𝑏𝑚𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑘2subscript𝑏𝑚superscript𝑘2subscriptsuperscript𝛿2𝑛2for-all𝑘d_{k}\leq\frac{(\sum_{m=1}^{M}a_{m}(k)|h_{m}(k)|b_{m}(k))^{2}}{\sum_{m=1}^{M}a_{m}(k)|h_{m}(k)|^{2}b_{m}(k)^{2}+\delta^{2}_{n}/2},\forall k and reformulate (37) as

min𝐀,𝐩,𝐝,𝝎,𝐲⁡log⁡(∑k=1Ke𝐜kT​𝐲)+1η​∑m=1MP​(𝐀,𝐀¯)subscript𝐀𝐩𝐝𝝎𝐲superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝐜𝑘T𝐲1𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀𝑃𝐀¯𝐀\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{A},\mathbf{p},\mathbf{d},\boldsymbol{\omega},\mathbf{y}}\quad\log\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}e^{\mathbf{c}_{k}^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{y}}\right)+\frac{1}{\eta}\sum_{m=1}^{M}P(\mathbf{A},\bar{\mathbf{A}}) (46a)
s.t. fk≥g​(𝐚k),∀k,subscript𝑓𝑘𝑔subscript𝐚𝑘for-all𝑘\displaystyle\quad f_{k}\geq g(\mathbf{a}_{k}),\forall k, (46b)
dk≤(∑m=1Mam​(k)​|hm​(k)|​bm​(k))2∑m=1Mam​(k)​|hm​(k)|2​bm​(k)2+δn2/2,∀k,subscript𝑑𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘subscriptℎ𝑚𝑘subscript𝑏𝑚𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑎𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑘2subscript𝑏𝑚superscript𝑘2subscriptsuperscript𝛿2𝑛2for-all𝑘\displaystyle\quad d_{k}\leq\frac{(\sum_{m=1}^{M}a_{m}(k)|h_{m}(k)|b_{m}(k))^{2}}{\sum_{m=1}^{M}a_{m}(k)|h_{m}(k)|^{2}b_{m}(k)^{2}+\delta^{2}_{n}/2},\forall k, (46c)
fk≤min⁡(2​L​pi−6​δ2δ2+α1,L​pK+k+μ−Lμ​α2),∀k,subscript𝑓𝑘2𝐿subscript𝑝𝑖6superscript𝛿2superscript𝛿2subscript𝛼1𝐿subscript𝑝𝐾𝑘𝜇𝐿𝜇subscript𝛼2for-all𝑘\displaystyle\quad f_{k}\leq\min\Big{(}\frac{2Lp_{i}-6\delta^{2}}{\delta^{2}+\alpha_{1}},\frac{Lp_{K+k}+\mu-L}{\mu\alpha_{2}}\Big{)},\forall k, (46d)
(​31b​),(​31c​),(​32d​).italic-(31bitalic-)italic-(31citalic-)italic-(32ditalic-)\displaystyle\quad\eqref{staleness},\eqref{active},\eqref{33d}. (46e)

When (46) is minimized, at the optimal point (46b) and (46c) must be held with equality; hence problem (46) is equivalent to problem (37).

Problem (46) now includes non-convex constraints (32d) and (46c). Denote {𝐀t,𝐲t}superscript𝐀𝑡superscript𝐲𝑡\{\mathbf{A}^{t},\mathbf{y}^{t}\} as the optimizer {𝐀,𝐲}𝐀𝐲\{\mathbf{A},\mathbf{y}\} obtained at the previous inner iteration. Note that (32d) is a constraint where a linear function is less than a convex function. Since the first-order Taylor expansion serves as a global lower bound of any convex function, (32d) can be convexified with a surrogate function by taking the first-order Taylor expansion to its right-hand side (RHS). We thus obtain (38c).

Furthermore, the RHS of (46c) is convex because it is a convex quadratic-over-linear function under a composition with affine mapping [31, Section 3.2]. Similarly, (46c) can be convexified by taking the first-order Taylor expansion to the RHS, as shown in (38e).

We now complete the convexification of all non-convex constraints in problem (37). The transformed problem is given in (38). Note that all the non-convex functions and their surrogate functions (derived via first-order Taylor expansion) have identical values and gradients at local point {𝐀t,𝐲t}superscript𝐀𝑡superscript𝐲𝑡\{\mathbf{A}^{t},\mathbf{y}^{t}\}. Moreover, the transformed problem satisfies the Slater’s condition. According to [34, Section III-B], the solution of (38) terminates at a KKT point of (37) and qualifies as a local minimum if it resides in the interior of (38)’s feasible set.
